questions.question_text: Identify the nets which can be used to make cubes (cut out copies of the nets and try it): (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v) (vi)
hints: Check if the net has exactly 6 squares
Ensure squares are arranged so they can fold into a cube without overlap
Opposite faces should not be adjacent in the net

questions.question_text: Dice are cubes with dots on each face. Opposite faces of a die always have a total of seven dots on them. Here are two nets to make dice (cubes); the numbers inserted in each square indicate the number of dots in that box. Insert suitable numbers in the blanks, remembering that the number on the opposite faces should total to 7.
hints: Remember opposite faces sum to 7: 1↔6, 2↔5, 3↔4
Visualize how the net folds into a cube
Check adjacent faces in the net won't become opposite in the cube

questions.question_text: Can this be a net for a die? Explain your answer.
hints: Check if all faces 1-6 are present exactly once
Verify opposite faces rule (sum to 7) can be satisfied when folded
Ensure the net can fold into a cube without overlap

questions.question_text: Here is an incomplete net for making a cube. Complete it in at least two different ways. Remember that a cube has six faces. How many are there in the net here? (Give two separate diagrams. If you like, you may use a squared sheet for easy manipulation.)
hints: A cube has 6 square faces
The incomplete net shows some squares already
Add missing squares ensuring they connect properly to form a valid net
There are multiple possible completions

questions.question_text: Match the nets with appropriate solids: (a) (i) (b) (ii) (c) (iii) (d) (iv)
hints: Identify the 3D shape each net would form when folded
Look for characteristic faces: triangles for pyramids, circles for cylinders/cones
Count faces and their shapes

questions.question_text: Use isometric dot paper and make an isometric sketch for each one of the given shapes: (i) (ii) (iii) (iv)
hints: Use isometric dot paper to maintain proportions
Start with the front face and work backwards
Use dotted lines for hidden edges

questions.question_text: The dimensions of a cuboid are 5 cm, 3 cm and 2 cm. Draw three different isometric sketches of this cuboid.
hints: Maintain exact proportions: 5:3:2
You can orient the cuboid differently in each sketch
All edges should be drawn to scale on isometric paper

questions.question_text: Three cubes each with 2 cm edge are placed side by side to form a cuboid. Sketch an oblique or isometric sketch of this cuboid.
hints: Resulting cuboid dimensions: length=6cm (2+2+2), breadth=2cm, height=2cm
Choose either oblique or isometric method
For oblique: front face true shape, receding edges at angle

questions.question_text: Make an oblique sketch for each one of the given isometric shapes:
hints: Oblique sketches don't need proportional lengths
Front face drawn true shape
Receding edges drawn at an angle (usually 45°)
Hidden edges as dotted lines

questions.question_text: Give (i) an oblique sketch and (ii) an isometric sketch for each of the following: (a) A cuboid of dimensions 5 cm, 3 cm and 2 cm. (Is your sketch unique?) (b) A cube with an edge 4 cm long.
hints: For (a): draw both oblique and isometric of 5×3×2 cuboid
For (b): draw both sketches of 4cm cube
Oblique: front face true, receding edges at angle; Isometric: all edges to scale
Sketches not unique - different orientations possible

questions.question_text: What cross-sections do you get when you give a (i) vertical cut (ii) horizontal cut to the following solids? (a) A brick (b) A round apple (c) A die (d) A circular pipe (e) An ice cream cone
hints: Vertical cut: parallel to vertical axis
Horizontal cut: parallel to ground/ base
Consider shape of solid and cutting plane
Brick: rectangular prism; Apple: sphere; Die: cube; Pipe: cylinder; Cone: cone

questions.question_text: A bulb is kept burning just right above the following solids. Name the shape of the shadows obtained in each case. Attempt to give a rough sketch of the shadow. (You may try to experiment first and then answer these questions). A ball (i) A cylindrical pipe (ii) A book (iii)
hints: Light directly above creates shadow similar to base shape
Ball (sphere): circular shadow
Cylindrical pipe: rectangular or circular depending on orientation
Book (cuboid): rectangular shadow

questions.question_text: Here are the shadows of some 3-D objects, when seen under the lamp of an overhead projector. Identify the solid(s) that match each shadow. (There may be multiple answers for these!) A circle (i) A square (ii) A triangle (iii) A rectangle (iv)
hints: Circle: sphere, cylinder (from top), cone (from base)
Square: cube, cuboid (from face)
Triangle: cone (from side), triangular prism
Rectangle: cuboid, cylinder (from side)

questions.question_text: Examine if the following are true statements: (i) The cube can cast a shadow in the shape of a rectangle. (ii) The cube can cast a shadow in the shape of a hexagon.
hints: (i) True: when light shines on cube at an angle, shadow can be rectangular
(ii) True: with specific light angles and surface orientations, cube can cast hexagonal shadow
Think about different orientations of cube relative to light source
